This post will hopefully give you some things to look out for as the results start to pour in tomorrow evening:

House

Republicans have a 232-201 majority.
Democrats need to pick up 17 seats for a majority.
They are projected to win anywhere between 10 and 40 seats, so we'll see what happens. There are a lot of key House races in New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Connecticut, as well as a few very interesting ones in Arizona and in traditionally red districts in Colorado, Wyoming, Nebraska, and Idaho.

Senate

Earlier in the year, taking back the Senate wasn't thought to be a realistic goal for Democrats. Because of the way things have been going, though, regaining a narrow majority is within striking distance.

The balance of power will be determined by these Senate races:

Virginia - Webb (D) vs. Allen (R)
Missouri - McCaskill (D) vs. Talent (R)
Montana - Tester (D) vs. Burns (R)
New Jersey - Menendez (D) vs. Kean (R)
Tennessee - Ford (D) vs. Corker (R)
Rhode Island - Whitehouse (D) vs. Chafee (R)
Connecticut - Lamont (D) vs. Lieberman (Douche) vs. Schlesinger (R)
Maryland - Cardin (D) vs. Steele (R)

Arizona

If you're in the 8th District, obviously Giffords is running against Graf. Giffords is probably going to win, even though I couldn't be any less impressed by what she brings to the table.

On the other hand, sometimes a good way to gauge a race is to look and see who's supporting candidate X or Y. People who hate Mexicans love Randy Graf, so....that's just kind of the way it is, probably not just in AZ-08, but a lot of districts across the country.

Renzi in the 1st district and Hayworth in the 5th district are also in a little bit of trouble, so instead of two Dem reps from Arizona (Grijalva and Pastor) it's possible we could end up with five, depending on how things go. Napolitano is going to win by about 7574108%, and Kyl looks like he's going to hold off Pederson in the Senate race - again, no guarantees of that though.

There are 17 propositions on the ballot. It took me 90 minutes while I was sitting at my desk to look up each one and figure out what the hell they were talking about, so that can't bode well for the level of voter education about these things. I hate direct democracy sometimes.

The main ones are these:

103 makes English the official language in Arizona
106 saves some trees
105 is a neutered version of 106 that people got on the ballot just to piss off the tree people
107 bans gay marriage, even though it's already banned
200 establishes a $1 million lottery that you enter just for voting (I actually voted for this, thinking hey, I don't pay income taxes yet, so I get a free lottery ticket, but I changed my mind about it - because I know that some rich jackass will probably end up winning. That's how it always goes. Kind of like some rich freshman girl always wins the car at the Salpointe raffle.)
201 bans smoking in all public places
202 raises the minimum wage
206 bans smoking in some places (so what if both pass? I'm confused)
204 says you're not allowed to tie your pig or cow to a tree for too long a period of time

That's about it.

I don't really see this as some kind of day of national awakening. If the Democrats happen to have a big day, that doesn't make the country automatically better or worse. The party hasn't done a whole hell of a lot to instill a lot of confidence in anyone. Will they work more? Will they take less money from the wrong people? Will they grow a spine? Will they balance the budget? Will they leave or fix or change Iraq? I don't think anyone can say for sure. After watching hours and hours of debates and ads and attacks and visions for the future, I don't have a whole lot of hope. Alycia laughed at an RNC ad she saw on Sunday that talked about someone named "Liberal Lois" over cartoon-type music because she said it sounded like it was talking to a bunch of little kids. That pretty much sums it up. Over the last six months whenever I try to get political news on TV I'm treated like a child, and that's pretty pathetic.

But I also disagree with people who say that voting is pointless because everyone's the same; the system is corrupt or coercive; partisan divisions on issues and discussions are meaningless. On a base level, I voted this year not particularly for Gabby Giffords or Jim Pederson or whoever, but against certain ideas whenever I could. A vote this year can be a vote against people who are involved in corruption and greed, people who preach hate, people who demonstrate ignorance and callousness on a daily basis. It can be against a legislative agenda that enables those characteristics. It can be a vote if nothing else, to curttail the recklessness of the executive.

It's not meaningless. Not voting because you have no idea what the hell is going on is completely defensible; telling everyone that "I'm not voting and you shouldn't either because it doesn't matter" is not. Obviously almost no one is going to have a perfect candidate or a perfect party to vote for. That's the way it goes. People are different from each other and they are individually different from the large groups that they make. Refusing to participate in the system we have for ourselves because you think we're all screwed anyway is the easy way out, and it's the least pragmatic thing you can do at a time like this.

Abstention on the grounds of ideological opposition. This means you're now the armchair quarterback. Not only are you not on the playing field, you're not even on the sidelines; you're not even wearing a uniform; you're not even in the booth calling the plays. You're sitting at home, cracking open a beer, telling yourself how you could easily call a better game than these idiots. It's the whole "I'm not losing because I'm not trying" bit.

I, along with most people, don't vote because I love my party or I love my candidate that much. Most voters are filled with just as much doubt and uncertainty as non-voters, only they choose to take the leap of faith that their guy is going to do a better job in the government we've set up for ourselves. There is a lot of messed up shit that takes place along the way, and dod knows there is more than enough shit out there to be cynical about - the money, the blood, the oil, the voting machines, the lobbyists, the grade-school discourse. In the end, though, you're going to have 100 Senators and 435 Representatives and they're going to head up to that building next year and hopefully try to do some things, and who we elect affects what those things are and how well they're done.

Tomorrow, we'll see if the pot gets stirred.

On the local WB affiliate the Maury show is always on when i get home from class, right after Jerry Springer.

Back in the old days, I always distinguished Maury from similar shows because it seemed like they always used to send teenagers to boot camp. I don't know what exactly they did, or for how long, because all we saw was some big guy in a military uniform would yell at the kids, take them away, and then bring them back cured; whatever the case, it seems that these days they've eschewed that concept to go strictly with shows featuring paternity tests.

On today's show there was a lady who came on who admitted that she had slept with her best friend's boyfriend, and she thought that the baby might be his. So they bring the best friend out and her boyfriend, and she doesn't know what's going on until her friend tells her, and she justifably freaks out and leaves the set and goes backstage. 

The thing I enjoy the most about this is that the producers of the show have a million cameras "backstage" anyway, as well as a feed that lets the audience see backstage on a huge TV monitor.

It turns out that it's not the boyfriend's kid after all; he seems pretty indifferent about the situation, even about the fact that his girlfriend is breaking up with him. Even more interesting, the best friend is comforting her "backstage" and telling Maury in between hugs that "We're gonna get through this," or "We're gonna work on this." 

The best friend, unconscionably, acts as if the fact that her baby isn't her best friend's boyfriend's means that all the other stuff about her moving to Whore Island didn't really happen either. Even more perplexing, the girlfriend seems to be willing to accept this.

In the next and vastly more entertaining segment, this lady is accusing a guy of being the father of her one-year-old. The guy comes out to a chorus of boos, then immediately wins the crowd over by taking out one of those little metal pointer things and pretending to educate everyone on the TV monitor why the baby doesn't look like him. This guy is either totally shameless, or he knows it's not his and that's why he can be this composed and charismatic at the same time.

Maury reads the results: it's not his. The girl runs away and cries "backstage" while the guy is just LOVING it. His delight reminded me of a Happy Gilmore celebration early in the movie, when he's high fiving everyone, throwing his arms up in the air, soaking it in, asking the crowd to get louder, while the totally underrated Verne Lundquist says things like "Quite a large and econonically diverse crowd here at the MicheIob Invitational."

Anyway, this made me wonder, what would I do if I was in that situation? I mean, this guy had to know beforehand that there was no chance he was the father - because if he actually had any doubt, there's no way he'd be running around stage like he just won a goddamn Showcase Showdown. I probably wouldn't go on the show in the first place, but if it was me I would probably stand up quietly and give a short, determined fist pump to the audience, similar to when Tiger Woods makes an 8 foot par putt in the 3rd round of the U.S. Open.

I don't know what to make of it. I think it's funny, because who are these people? At the same time, I always preferred Jenny Jones, when she had that Rude Jude guy on; this white gangster guy who looked and talked like Eminem, and they always brought him in to make fun of fat or ugly or ridiculous girls. Rude Jude always delivered.

Maybe I can bring it up in American Studies class, in between people who raise their hands to offer their own personal experiences as arguments for or against social issues.

"My boyfriend is in Iraq, and he says they never talk about the good things that happen there."

"I have a lot of black friends, and none of them agree with affirmative action."

"My boyfriend's mom has Parkinson's, and she is against stem cell research."

Awesome.

One of the required classes Penn State makes you take is CAS 100A - Effective Public Speaking.

The way it works in this class is that you and 29 other poor assholes have to take turns writing and delivering a series of speeches. You have to give a "Speech of Introduction", a "Cultural Artifiact Presentation", a "Problem Speech", a "Policy Speech", a "Motivational Speech", and a "Commemorative Speech".

For the problem, policy and motivational speeches, you are supposed to pick the same topic and, in three separate speeches, outline the problem, then give a solution, then tell people to do something about it. The topic has to be some kind of social issue that should be of concern to the audience, who is, like I said, the teacher and all the other poor bastards who have to listen to you.

Being the stupid fucking socialist that I am, of course I pick the minimum wage, on the grounds that it was the easiest, most straightforward thing I could think of at the time.

In hindsight, I should have picked something that went against my beliefs, like why we should all be anti-abortion or why we need tougher drug laws, or why George Bush is the right man for the job. It would have been a lot more fun, and there's not a lot of conscience involved in writing the speech when you know you'll just be standing up there for 7 minutes and lying to people left and right.

Instead I pick the minimum wage, and I did the first speech and it went okay, because it's easy to point out that hey, if you work full time and you make minimum wage, you're still going to be dirt-ass poor; and that is a decent enough slap in the face to people who think everyone is just great around here. But now I'm writing the policy section and I want to punch a wall.

I have a few decent arguments, but I don't even believe them anymore. I don't believe anything about the minimum wage. I no longer have an opinion. If I had a vote, I would probably still approve a hike in the minimum wage, but only because it really has no effect on me, since I doubt I'll be making or paying out minimum wage anytime soon.

The problem lies in the fact that I'm not an economist, nor have I taken any sort of class in economics. 

Just because you have done one or more of those things doesn't necessarily make you qualified to talk about it, of course, since you might be an idiot; but the bottom line is that most economists believe that raising the minimum wage causes higher rates of unemployment.

When people study what happens to our job opportunities when we've decided to raise the minimum wage, though, "this theoretical prediction has, however, been hard to confirm with actual data", as Paul Krugman writes. So although it makes sense that we would lose jobs whenever we raised it, for whatever reason, it doesn't seem to happen.

Still, though, I've read enough free-market, libertarian bullshit in the last three days that I'm now uncomfortable with taking a stand either way. I don't feel comfortable arguing for something that in theory hurts the people that it's supposed to benefit. I don't want poor people to lose their shitty jobs just so other poor people can be a little less poor - I mean, who would? It would kind of defeat the purpose of the whole idea.

I'm not going to go more into it because it's not worth it; like I said, I don't know what I'm talking about. The bottom line is that it depends on who you believe. There are politicians and economists and think tanks on each side of the argument who will look you straight in the eye and convincing you that they're right and everyone else is a retard.

This is an increasing trend, and a very depressing one, in my opinion. Now that we have the internet, it's easy (if you're not a hardheaded ideological piece of shit) to go from being committed to a certain cause to a person without any conviction in anything. Very few people actually do that, obviously, but it's certainly possible: if you were trying to educate yourself about an issue, and you didn't carry any ideological biases going into it, I really think that you could study for six months and not come out of it any more sure of yourself than you did when you first started.

This is what happens in a world that gets grayer and grayer by the day. When I was a senior in high school, I wrote a bunch of articles in my school newspaper for a "left v. right" column; I wouldn't be able to do that anymore, not because I'm not still a lefty, but because I no longer would be able to provide any answers for the problem that they put in front of me. 

For example, I wrote about illegal immigration; I really have no fucking idea what to do about that. I think Tom Tancredo and most of the Minutemen are racists, and so I'm against any cause that racists feel compelled to advocate; beyond that, I couldn't tell you.

Likewise, I'm voting for all Democrats next week, not necessarily because I think that they're just awesome, but because I think the people in charge are jackasses, and are killing people, stealing our money and lying about it. Am I for raising the minimum wage, or universal health care, or fair trade, or pulling out our troops? Shit, how am I supposed to know? At this point, I just want whoever is in charge to just leave us all alone.

I guess I am in favor of a Democratic agenda, even though a) they're probably not going to end up doing shit anyway and b) I'm a 19-year-old college sophomore studying journalism in central Pennsylvania, and I really wouldn't know any better; all I can go by is what I hear and see, and what I choose to believe or call bullshit on. You could be against all of those things that I mentioned and I certainly wouldn't accuse you of intellectual dishonesty.

So I have to finish writing this speech, and the more I read and learn, the exponentially more difficult it becomes to write the speech with any sort of conviction. I just hate it when people come up there and start giving their speech and it sounds like they have barely even though about it, they just went with the first thing that sounded good - and that's going to end up being me, tomorrow morning, because I don't really have a choice. The sad thing is that I doubt anyone will really notice or care all that much.  Half of the people in the class who have any interest in the issue will just accept whatever arguments I make as gospel truth, and half will think I'm full of shit, and no one will say anything about it.

My ethos is getting smaller and smaller by the day; it's shrinking like a piece of fruit that someone left out in the sun. I hate school.

I have to go to class right now, but I was watching George Bush's speech on the television. He is at the United Nations, I guess. Why did the United Nations even let him waste their time? You'd think they would all get together and say "You know, thanks for the offer, but New Zealand and Peru really have some good stuff this year, so we're gonna have to take a pass."

I know that it's really not that funny, but I still laughed at him. What a hopeless guy. No one even pays attention to him anymore.

It's strange to think of a U.S. President as being completely irrelevant, yet that's really how it seems like.

Even the UN countries listening to the speech seem to be like "Yeah, yeah, whatever." Leaning back in their chairs, talking to the guy next to them, frowning, staring off into space.

I think the reason why watching a Bush speech is funny is that he really doesn't appear to understand what he's saying. Have you ever heard his answers when people ask him unscripted questions? None of his answers make any sense. When he reads a speech it's like some 8th grader doing a presentation on Vasco da Gama that he copied directly from the encyclopedia.

He is talking to the people of Darfur now. I don't think Darfur is a country, so I'm not sure they would be there. Also, anything Bush says about Darfur is basically spitting in the face of whoever is listening, since everyone obviously knows that he isn't planning on doing shit about it.

I think it would be fun to know where the two black guys on screen are from, and what they're talking about. I just picture like Liberia and the Central African Republic making jokes about Bush's weird facial expressions or something.

Watching this guy up here talking about peace and diplomacy and democracy, I feel like I would have the same feeling listening to Barry Bonds talk to a bunch of kids about staying off drugs. It's just like, who are you kidding, anyway?

After he finished he got a golf clap, not a birdie clap but a routine par clap.

I am late.

Facebook, all things considered, has treated me well over the past year. It makes it very easy to keep in touch with people and see what they are up to. I don't think it was necessary to expand it to high schools - I can tell already that it is spreading like wildfire at Salpointe now that some cool kids have their accounts - but all in all, it's a good thing to pass the time and keep up with your friends, particularly when you're someone like me and you didn't go to college with any of them. I could appreciate the photo album feature, the global group thing is useful, I think the status and the notes thing is pretty useless but it's not that big of a deal.

(By the way, I somehow managed to make this livejournal an RSS feed into my facebook notes; it is pretty much overkill , but good for one stop shopping I guess, and now people can read the stupid shit that I write even if they don't actually talk to me, but are somehow friends with me on Facebook. Great.)

Unfortunately, this morning they decided to cross the line.

Now they have this ridiculous feature called "News Feed" which is basically a wall of omniscience. It is basically a list of every possible action of your Facebook friends that the site could possibly track; what groups they join and leave and create, when they change their status, any modifications, minor or major, they make on their profile, who they became friends with, when they were mentioned in a note, changes in relationships, new photos. If you do something and you don't want anyone to know about it, well, you have to do it first and then "hide" it.



[It's going to be weird looking at the image of Facebook on Facebook. That doesn't even make any sense]

Why?

Why would this be a positive development in any way? Why make it easier for people to find out unnecessary information about what you're doing on their dumbass website?

Where, exactly, does Facebook intend on going from here? I don't know what is in the works, but I can't think of anything else they would be interested in tracking.

The Setup:

Brady Quinn is the quarterback for Notre Dame. He is widely considered to be the front-runner in the race for the Heisman, and will probably go #1 in the NFL draft next year.

In the intrest of full disclosure, I should say that I don't really like Notre Dame. Kind of like how I feel about Duke, except I hate Duke 34985 times more.

This is where it gets almost too good to be true.

Brady Quinn has an older sister.


But no ordinary older sister. See, she happened to be engaged (at the time) all-american linebacker for the Packers, formerly of Ohio State.

A.J. Hawk is a large and powerful man.



She was faced with quite a problem last January, when Ohio State was playing Notre Dame, and the circumstances were such that her boyfriend, in an effort to win the game, was doing his best to hit her little brother as hard as he could in the chest. That's just what linebackers are supposed to do, it doesn't matter if it's your girlfriend's brother or not.

Who would she root for, though? As it turns out, both.



That was at last year's Fiesta Bowl. This became a running joke among everyone I know who watched the game, especially when ABC seemed transfixed by the whole situation. They even sent Jack Arute, the sideline reporter, to interview her, which turned out hilariously when all he did was flash a goofy smile the whole time and pretty much hit on her while she was trying to watch the game. Brent Musberger was his usual ridiculous self.

A.J.  Hawk sacked Brady Quinn, and Laura Quinn made a face.

We also know that Laura Quinn isn't the brightest apple on the tree.

So anyway, they got married this year, and Notre Dame went down to Atlanta to play Georgia Tech on Saturday. The College Gameday crew was there, which meant a lot of this:





Fans love holding up signs supporting their team, belittling the opponent, and cheering boistrously behind the crew as the three guys are doing the show. So there were a lot of Georgia Tech fans taking advantage of this situation.

The Punchline:

One of these fans was holding up a memorable sign on Saturday that made me laugh for ten minutes straight, and Deadspin caught it as well:

"Brady Quinn's sister loves the D."

I don't care who you are, that's just funny.

It has been raining for almost 24 hours now.

People have been saying that it's because we are catching the remnants of Tropical Storm Ernesto.

This is false. God, actually, is punishing Penn State.

God is punishing my school and its 79-year-old football coach, Joe Paterno, for having such a weak, pathetic home non-conference schedule this year.

Penn State goes to Notre Dame one week from today. But as for the remainder of the non-conference slate? Akron (today's opponent), Temple and...drumroll please...the Youngstown State Penguins. Come on. give us a Colorado State or Missouri, or maybe a Maryland or Washington.

And so it rains. I didn't go to the game, because I do not have season tickets. I do not wish to elaborate why I do not, except to say that demand is high.

However, it was really terrible outside, mid-50's, wet, windy, miserable, and so I watched it from the comfort of my dorm room.

Penn State won comfortably, and sloppily, 34-16. Two fumbles and a number of errant passes, but the defense was good. It's worth noting that Dan Connor played better than Paul Posluszny, who is overrated (which isn't his fault at all), but it was good to see that the new safeties and defensive linemen performed admirably.

Akron did the best they could, but they are Akron, and nothing will ever change that.

We now have a large amount of very fast, skilled recievers: Derrick Williams, Deon Butler, Terrell Golden, Jordan Norwood, A.J. Wallace, Chris Bell.

Our quarterback has a really, really big nose, but a very good arm, so I guess that evens out, except I fear that it (nose) might get broken at some point.

I am waiting for 10:15 ET to come around; Arizona plays BYU on TBS. I'm very excited for this Arizona football season; it's more fun, actually, than basketball season. The reverse is true at Penn State; PSU basketball, in my opinion, is more fun than PSU football.

The reason for this is because, simply put, it's not as fun rooting for a team who you expect to win pretty much every game. The corollary of this is that it isn't fun at all when you're watching a game and merely hoping that your team doesn't lose.

That was Arizona basketball the last two years; we're playing Oregon State or Washington, and everyone I know is just hoping, praying, that we don't lose, because we are supposed to win. If we lose, it sucks; if we win, we only did what we were supposed to. There are none of those crazy, unexpected, nonsensically glorious victories, like a Penn State team who started no one bigger than 6'6 going on the road to beat Dee Brown and Illinois last spring when a buzzer-beating Illinois three-pointer was waived off after five minutes of replay. Similarly, UA football has the UCLA game last year.

PSU football and UA basketball have their down years, but the prestige of their respective programs is such that "big" wins never happen anymore, unless it's a bowl game, or a rivalry game, or an important bowl/tournament game. And you know what? I'm going to go ahead and say it, that really sucks. UA basketball fans were miserable last year and the year before that, even though they won 20 games each of those seasons. That's just the way it is.

Hello.

My name is Dylan. I own a Hyundai, and my sister thinks it is ugly.

She didn't say it to my face, but I can tell. I can definitely tell.

It is kind of ugly. I have owned it for eight days. Oh well. It happens.

I could have told her that my car thinks she is ugly, but that's a very childish thing to say, and everyone who reads this knows that I prefer to take the high road in situations like that.

I am still alive. I don't update my live journal very much anymore. My writing was becoming very poor and it was making me sad, so I stopped.

I hate how it looks now. Maybe I will get a new website or something. It depends if I remember how to write. I looked at some of the things I wrote a year ago and I do not even recognize the person who wrote them. I could not write like that if I tried.

For whatever reason, everything has gradually become a lot less interesting - which makes a person's writing a lot more apathetic, and boring, and therefore pointless.

Here are a few paragraphs to allow me to catch up a little bit, for record keeping purposes if nothing else. When I become a decrepit and senile bastard, I want to be able to look back on the year 2006 and remember what happened.

Never mind. I will probably just lie about it, tell my grandson I was in the goddamn Peace Corps or the 10st Airborne division in Nazi Germany or something. He probably wouldn't figure it out until I was dead anyway. "Grandpa, I didn't know you were 153 years old this year..."

I did not get a job this summer. I did not really want a job, but I applied at 12-15 different businesses anyway and was not called back.

I believe it could be because I have an armed robbery conviction on my record. I never was convicted of armed robbery, but it's possible that someone could have made a mistake.

The one thing worth mentioning about my summer was the trip I went on in May. Two friends and I went to a bunch of different places. We drove 3800 miles in a big circle around the western United States.

Five hours into the trip, Sproul left his cell phone at a rest stop. We played football and wiffle ball on Mission Beach. One day into the trip, Sproul lost his camera charger.

We were in the live studio audience for the Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson. To this day I do not know why. One of the comedians was very funny; Craig Ferguson was moderately funny. The audience laughed at a lot of things that weren't funny. We had a bet on what the musical guest would be (there was none); Sproul had the best guess (Los Lonely Boys).

We got a parking ticket on Hollywood Blvd. Our meter ran out when Sproul and Martin were looking for Chris Farley's star. Typical.

We went to Six Flags Magic Mountain. I got stuck on the top of the fucking rotating tower for 20 minutes while Martin and Sproul searched the park for me. I rode on roller coasters, even though I hate roller coasters. We won a purple snake and named it Sissy.

Ricky Williams will continue to play professional football with the CFL's Toronto Argonauts while he is suspended for one year by the NFL, and one high-profile ex-Argonaut isn't thrilled by the move.

Former quarterback Joe Theismann, who began his professional career with the Argonauts and later went on to star in the NFL with the Redskins, said he was "embarrassed right now to be a Toronto Argonaut" in an interview with ESPN Radio's Colin Cowherd. "

I don't ever want to be mentioned in the same breath as Ricky Williams as a football player. He's a disgrace to the game. The man doesn't deserve to play football. He should go on with his life and treat his drug addictions or go do whatever he wants to do. He's been suspended from the National Football League on multiple occasions. Doesn't anybody have any class anywhere? For gosh sakes, let the kid go do what he wants to do. He doesn't want to play football," Theismann, who is part of ESPN's Monday Night Football announcing crew, said.

Williams was suspended by the NFL for the entire 2006 season following a fourth positive drug test. But the Dolphins gave him permission to play this year in the CFL, and he signed with Toronto on Sunday.

Theismann, while calling Williams a "good kid" said he believes that the running back has had too many chances.

"We have rules in the National Football League. It's real simple. Don't do drugs and you can play. It's a privilege to be able to play professional football. It's not some rite of passage. He's insulted the Miami Dolphins after they took him back and gave him a chance to play. Now he insults the intelligence of everybody that thinks that doing drugs is OK. To me, it's the wrong message to send to kids. It's the wrong thing to be doing, and the Toronto Argonauts have embarrassed themselves as an organization signing him," Theismann said.

Toronto has won the Grey Cup -- the CFL championship -- 15 times, most recently in 2004. The Argonauts were 11-7 last season.

I never really felt strongly one way or the other about Ricky Williams, even though we do go way back. The second sports video game I ever owned, right after I bought Triple Play 97, was NCAA Football 98 for PC. I got it for Christmas from my parents, and I played it for hours on end until school started in January, when I had to put it away because I was grounded from the computer by my parents for getting bad grades.

I always played with Arizona - Keith Smith, Trung Candidate, Jeremy McDaniel, Dennis Northcutt, Marcus Bell, Chris McAllister - that was quite a year indeed - but my little brother, who was about 7 or 8 at the time (and ironically has no interest in sports whatsoever anymore) wanted to play too, so he picked Texas. Luckily for him, they had Ricky Williams, who was unstoppable. My brother called the same play - Toss Right - every time, and Ricky would either outrun the entire secondary for an 80 yard TD or truck a few linebackers, cut back, and run for a more exciting 80 yard TD. On the hardest level, my brother, who knew little about football, was beating the best teams (UCLA, Florida State, Tennessee) 98-7 and running for 650 yards a game with Ricky, who won the Heisman in real life that year.

Everyone knew from the beginning that he was a weird guy, from the SI cover when he posed with Ditka in a wedding dress, to doing interviews with his helmet on, to hiring Master P as his agent and getting a horrible rookie deal, his dreads, etc, etc. Then two years ago, he retired at the age of 27, with little explanation. The news articles said he quit for a combination of reasons: he was getting suspended for smoking pot, he wanted to travel the world, he just plain didn't care about football and didn't want to play anymore.

This was in July of 2004, and on every TV and sports radio station he was being ripped by everyone, from sportswriters to former players to teammates. He quit on his team. He is the lowest of the low. He is a horrible teammate. Pothead. Crazy person. Unreliable. Selfish. No heart.

A year later, he came back to the Dolphins, sat out 4 games, then backed up Ronnie Brown. He was accepted immediately by his teammates and his new coach, ran for 750 yards and a few touchdowns.

Failed his 4th drug test, lost his appeal a month ago, and was suspended from the NFL for a year. Got ripped again by Skip Bayless and the guys from Around the Horn and whoever the hell else felt the need to chime in about how they were right about Ricky the first time.

Today he signed with the Toronto Argonauts with the CFL. I watched the press conference. Ordinarily I would have turned the channel, but listening to Ricky talk was so interesting to me that I kept it on for another half hour until the NFL Network ended the feed.

When Ricky spoke, it was about 10% football and 90% other. He mentioned helping the team be successful, mentioned his new coach, his teammates, giving it 100% on the field, being thankful for the opportunity, and looking forward to returning to the Dolphins in 2007. This is what you would hear in a prototypical press conference when a new player comes to a team, so that really wasn't extraordinary in any way.

What I gathered from the rest of the things he said and the way he said them was that Ricky Williams is about as far away, personality wise, from a stereotypical professional athlete as you can get. He was shy and talked quietly. He would make a remark, everyone would chuckle even though he wasn't trying to be funny, just honest, and he would get this small, sheepish grin on his face while he waited for everyone to calm down again. (For example, when someone asked him if he was going to be drug tested by the Toronto organization, he said with a straight face that the NFL was already testing him about 10 times a month, so he thought that they pretty much had it covered.)

The thing that struck me the most was how unbelievably honest and down to earth the guy was when the writers asked him for various explanations for the things he had done in the past. When a guy asked him if the reason why he was playing this year instead of sitting out was financial (he owes the Dolphins $8.6 million for breaching his contract in 04) he hesitated and then said "...you obviously make money playing football than you do sitting at home."

He didn't mention at all dominating the league, or leading the league in rushing or touchdowns, or even winning a championship.

It was obvious that he didn't care. He doesn't care about football at all, he could give a shit about how many yards he runs for or whether he wins any awards or whatever. This guy was and still is one of the best ten guys in the world at taking the football and gaining yardage against other players, and he was arguably the greatest college running back of all time at Texas. And after listening to him for a half hour I could tell that he couldn't care less about what he was doing or what people thought about him.

When he retired two years ago, he said  "I just don't want to be in this business anymore. I was never strong enough to not play football, but I'm strong enough now. I've considered everything about this. Everyone has thrown every possible scenario at me about why I shouldn't do this, but they're in denial. I'm happy with my decision. I'm finally free. I can't remember ever being this happy."

While he was away, he said "I'm closer to being happy. I'm doing things that make me happy. In football I loved to practice and I loved to play, but I hated to be in meetings, hated to talk to the media, hated to have cameras in my face, hated to sign autographs. I hated to do all those things."

At the press conference he talked about his year away from football, how he traveled all over the world, sleeping in tents in Australia and India, reading books. When a Canadian reporter asked him to describe himself, he called himself a "seeker", saying that he was a guy who had all of the material possessions very early in his life, realized soon afterwards that all of the money and fame and security meant nothing to him, and who up until a year and a half ago felt unfulfilled and confused about his life. He said he was someone searching for himself, searching for God, searching for inner peace, all of those things fit a description of him.

I don't know why I found the whole thing so fascinating, but it struck a chord. Here's a guy who is rich and famous, a person with born with unbelievable physical talent, a guy who played pro baseball and pro football, the latter at the higest possible level. A guy who was the best in the world at what he did, a guy with millions of dollars and all the notoriety that came along with being a pro athlete, a high profile life. And he hated it so much that he quit. He came back after a year because as it turned out, he no longer had any money, and he knew that a) money enabled him to do the things he wanted to do in his life, and b) he now understood the good things that could come from playing again, on both himself, in the joy of running between the tackles, and the people around him, who might be positively influenced by his success and work ethic. It's really, really strange to hear someone like Ricky, when your entire life you've been watching athletes who are totally, relentlessly committed to their sport, not just physical dedication but what it really meant to them to win or be an All-Star or whatever.

To me, it put a lot of things into perspective, at least as a fan of sports themselves. Seeing a guy like Ricky walk out onto the field in an Argonauts uniform and win games for them, even though I have the background knowledge that he doesn't care all that much about what happens in the end. It clashes to a mind-boggling degree with the fundamental nature of football itself, which is two teams with eleven men lining up opposite each other and trying to hit each other as hard as they can, regardless of the threat of severe physical injury.

It's crazy when you think about it. Ricky Williams has caught more shit than 99.9% of people will ever experience in their lives, simply because he treats football like a regular job instead of the all-consuming driving force in his life or the most important thing that he will do while he was alive on Earth. The guy quit his job because he was sick of it, and walked away from everything even though he was the best at what he did. Why is that perfectly okay for a normal person to do, but unacceptable and pathetic for Ricky Williams? How can the sports world be so callous, or ignorant, as to condemn a guy who is actually aware that there might be other, and perhaps vastly more important, things in life than playing football?

I love watching, and playing, sports more than anyone could ever know. I love the drama and the difficulty and the competition and the unpredictability and the celebration of how great people really can be at what they do, and the cheering and the sounds and the scoreboard and the trophies.

Ricky Williams works harder than anyone. He plays harder than anyone. He is (obviously) a terrific player. He doesn't want to be a football star. He doesn't want to be in the spotlight. He has been trying to balance the weight of the expectations of everyone around him with his own desire to figure out what really matters in life for the better part of a decade, succeeding at times, failing in others.

It saddens me to see how difficult it is for everyone to just leave him alone.

I'm going to give you two players, Player A and Player B, and we'll do a little comparison.

Player A is a 6'3, 197 pound shooting guard. In his four years in college, he averaged 14.5 points a game on 45.1% field goal shooting. He was 342/802 from three point line, at an outstanding 42.6% clip. He also averaged 2.9 rebounds per game and 1.9 assists per game, while only playing a suprising 28.8 minutes a game. 

Player B is a 6'4, 190 pound shooting guard. In his four years in college, he averaged 19.9 points a game on 43.2% field goal shooting. He was 457/1126 from long range over the course of his career, which is a 40.6% 3 point percentage. He also averaged 2.9 rebounds and 2.4 assists per game, while playing 36.6 minutes per game.

The scouting report on player A:
"He is a great shooter. Not a good shooter, but a great shooter. He can hit the standstill jumper or coming off screens, and he does a nice job of hitting the runner when he can get by his man. If you foul him, he hits his free throws. Ready for the knocks on him? He has great difficulty moving his feet. He struggles to get his own shot. He cannot stay in front of any reputable NBA guard on the defensive end. In short, he is as slow as molasses in January. He will be an NBA player because he has a needed skill that is absent from the NBA -- he can really shoot the ball."

The scouting report on player B:
"One of the two or three best pure shooters in the country. His shooting mechanics are flawless, and he possesses very deep range on his jumper. Has a quick release that lets him get his shot off in most situations. He's also a dead-eye from the free-throw line. Has diversified his offensive game a bit this season and is now putting the ball on the floor and getting to the rim. Despite a general lack of athleticism, he's not a bad defender. He's undersized to play the two in the NBA. Combine that with a lack of of lateral quickness, and scouts aren't sure exactly how his game will translate at the next level. Even though he seems to have diversified his game greatly, scouts seriously wonder if he'll be able to get to the rim and create his own shot off the dribble at the next level."

Player A was the second leading scorer on his team his junior and senior years, and was MVP of the East Regional in the NCAA tournament his senior year. His team fell in the National Championship game, but he had 25 points in a losing effort. He missed a two potential game winning shots in the last minute of the final, but after the game his coach said of him, "I want [him] to take that shot. I will win or lose with [him]. I will walk down any road with [him]...The ball was in our best player's hands with an opportunity to win the game."

Player B also went to the final four, in his sophomore year. His team lost in the national semifinal, though he was 4-12 for 15 points in the game. In four NCAA tournament losses, he was 13-60 (22 percent). He didn't take the last shot.

Player A played with terrific players like Elton Brand, Shane Battier, Mike Dunleavy and Corey Magette. Player B also had some talent surrounding him, like Luol Deng, Shelden Williams, Shavlik Randolph, Chris Duhon and Dahntay Jones.

Player A is Trajan Langdon, the "Alaskan Assassin." He played at Duke and was drafted 12th by Cleveland, just behind Shawn Marion and Jason Terry, ahead of current NBA stars Corey Magette, Andrei Kirilenko and Ron Artest, and also ahead of solid league contributors like James Posey, Kenny Thomas and Devean George.

Trajan Langdon's NBA career:

3 seasons, 119 games, 14.5 minutes, 5.4 points a game, 39% 3 point shooting. Out of the league in 2002. Played in Italy for Bennetton Treviso in 2002-2003, then went to Turkey for a year, and is currently playing in Russia.

Player B is J.J. Redick. J.J. Redick is Trajan Langdon, except he's white and he got to shoot more. He's not Jeff Hornacek. Jeff Hornacek shot 47% for his career, and 49% in college. In addition, Hornacek wasn't such a defensive liability, and he was an outstanding passer, and he also played in an era where every shooting guard wasn't 6'5 or taller. Hornacek never had to shoot every night over tall, athletic guys like Kobe, Wade, T-Mac, Ray Allen, Vince Carter, Jason Richardson, Rip Hamilton, Manu, Michael Redd, or Bruce Bowen or Trenton Hassell.

Would I take Redick if I'm an NBA GM? Sure, if he's still available in the second round. Give me Brandon Roy, or Randy Foye, or Mardy Collins, or Ronnie Brewer, or Maurice Ager. Hell, I'll take Hassan Adams, Mike Gansey, or Quincy Douby. I'm not gonna be the guy who takes Trajan Langdon, or the shorter version of Kyle Korver.

My last entry was 4200 words, so let's cut to the chase.

To make this go faster, we'll assume you picked all the top 4 seeds to advance to the second round. Can one of those 16 teams lose? Of course - look at Vermont and Bucknell last year. But I don't have the time to give you guidance on what to do with Davidson or Xavier in the second round. If you're going to pick a massive upset, you are a renegade and you don't need my help.

Here's a rule of thumb: if you're not sure who you like in a first round game, you obviously shouldn't take the winner of what you percieve to be a coin flip in the second round. Say you are faced with a tough 7-10 matchup and you're torn. Why the hell would you pick them to go on past the 2 in the second round? You're looking at a 50% chance of winning in the first, then maybe a 40% shot at best in the second. That's a 1 in 5 shot, which is a pretty dumb overall choice over the 3 seed (90%, then 60%, which is 54% of going through). Much better, wouldn't you say? The point is, if you want to pick a Cinderella, you better be pretty damn sold on them.

Montana looked impressive against NAU, but not impressive enough to convince me that they will beat Nevada. The potential second-round matchup against an underseeded BC team has all the makings of a showdown you'd normally see in the Sweet 16 or Elite 8. Nevada is riding a long winning streak, and this is a team who beat Texas (sans Tucker and Aldridge) in the first round last year.

4) Boston College vs. 13) Pacific

This is another game that could absolutely ruin people early on. A bunch of ESPN guys have BC going to the Final Four. I think that's a dicey pick. I don't see BC beating Nevada, Villanova, and either Ohio State or Florida to get there. That's simply too much to ask. Be prepared to laugh if BC goes down and people's brackets' are ruined 3 hours into Thursday play. 6) Oklahoma vs. 11) Wisconsin-Milwaukee

Overrated big-name higher seed from a power conference? Check. Experienced underdog who has made a splash before? Check. Neutral site (Jacksonville)? Check. Prove me wrong, Taj Gray and Terrell Everett. Don't pull an Alabama and sleepwalk your way into an insurmountable hole against these guys. Joah Tucker was ridiculously good last year. They also have Boo Davis and the big guy Tigert anchoring the middle. This is yet another early game that might screw people one way or the other. Don't feel bad if you turn on the TV after the first slot of games on Thursday and you're 0-4.

3) Florida vs. 14) South Alabama

Florida should win this game, but South Alabama absolutely destroyed a solid Western Kentucky team in the Sun Belt final. I don't know much about them, but Florida has fallen to Creighton and Manhattan as a 5 seed with more talent than they have now. If Florida is awake they should destroy USA on the boards. Does South Alabama bring back any memories? That's the team who was leading Arizona by 10 with 8 minutes to go as a 13 seed in first round of the 1997 tournament. UA went on a 22-4 to end the game and started the run that ended in a national title.

7) Georgetown vs. 10) Northern Iowa

The fact of the matter is that Georgetown is better than Northern Iowa, so you have to pick them. If you pick the lesser team and they lose, you can only blame yourself. Georgetown has great size with Hibbert and heady forwards in Green and Bowman. UNI got in only because they beat Missouri State in the MVC tournament; they were lucky to get by Bucknell in double OT at home. How Bradley is a 13 and UNI is a 10 is questionable when you consider that Bradley blew out UNI late in the season during their winning streak that carried them to the MVC tourney title game. Yes, the Panthers beat Iowa and beat LSU on the road, but that was early in the season. Do they have a shot? Absolutely. But the way they're playing, I'd be very surprised if they upset Georgetown.

2) Ohio State vs. 15) Davidson

I love Ohio State. I love Dials inside, Sylvester's clutch shooting, Foster and Butler in the backcourt, and I really really like J.J. Sullinger as an all-around player. I think before you look at BC coming out of this bracket, you have to look at Ohio State first. Big Ten regular season champs, talent everywhere. They hit a bump in the title game against Iowa, but they won't see a defensive team like them anywhere in this bracket. If they're hitting their threes, no one is going to beat them, and even if they're not, Davidson doesn't stand a chance.

So there you go. I'm not listing who I'm picking, one because I haven't decided on all of them yet, and two because you just don't do that before the tournament starts. Tomorrow we'll go over potential second, third and fourth round matchups. I hope some of this proves to be useful.

I am by nature an unhappy person.

I have way too much money for someone who hasn't worked for shit since he was 15.

I am smarter than everyone else so I don't have to study for anything. I can get at worst a C and at best a 100 on whatever I do.

People used to like my blog back when I wrote in it.

No one cares if I want to sit in my room all day and listen to Shakira and watch West Wing DVD's. I don't listen to Shakira.

I can drink as much Wild Cherry Pepsi as I want, even though I gotta tell you it's getting pretty goddamn disgusting.

I am halfheartedly playing out the conclusion of Western Illinois' third straight conference defeat, this one at home to Southern Utah. I've never figured out why I give myself so many headaches, trying to take a team nobody cares about from a school nobody's ever heard of and make them into a winner, year after year, in every video game I play. No one can shoot, one guy can rebound, and that tells the story of the 05-06 Leathernecks. A light knock on the open door, and an interested face peers in.
"What's goin' on, man? Aiyyo, is that the new one?"
It's one of the kids from directly across the hall. We have the same scholarship. I haven't really talked to him; then again, I haven't really talked to anyone. He seems like a nice guy, though. I saw him at the basketball season opener. You've gotta be a fan if you're willing to show up for that shit.
"Yeah." One word answer. My specialty.
"How is it? I got NBA Live, but I wanted this one, you can export the players into the draft right?"
"Oh...yeah, you can definitely do that. This plays different from Live, it's a lot about passing and defense, way more of a team game."
"Really? Oh, man, that's great, that's what I like." I am a bit surprised. If you looked at this kid you'd think he would be into the whole And 1 mixtape/NBA Street thing. He watches me finish my pathetic double digit loss.
"You want to play?"
He accepts and I offer him a chair. Illinois vs. Arizona gets underway. He takes a huge lead going into halftime. I rally in the last few minutes and tie it with 11 seconds to play. In between then, we talk casually, not confined to but primarily about sports. A fadeaway Dee Brown three-pointer over two guys at the buzzer. 78-75. He blows me out in the rematch.
"Hey, man, you have a safe holiday, take it easy."
"Thanks, you too."
I used to live in Tucson, Arizona, a part of the world that he certainly has not the faintest understanding of its essence. Likewise, he is from The Bronx, New York. As you know, I am light skinned, and as you might have imagined, he is not. He is majoring in engineering, and I most certainly am not. We have nothing in common other than this one innocuous bond; there is no sense denying that. Both of us understand one small part of each other, though, and as far as I know, that is all that matters.

Scene.

Couldn't be more than five or six hours later. Standing outside the greyhound station, cold. Nine months ago, when I returned to Pittsburgh for the first time since I was born there in 1986, I liked it; I liked that it had character, I liked the old, tall, sad buildings, the hills and the waterfront and the grit and determination and the ghosts of American blue-collar life. But as I stare out at the rusty suspension bridge sagging over the Ohio, waiting for cab 380 to take me to the La Quinta Inn, I feel nothing but a bitter and deeply irrational emnity towards the Steel City.

Of course it isn't fair. Of course not everyone in Pittsburgh is completely backwards, of course not everyone is filled with intolerance and homophobia and ignorance, of course not everyone is pale or obese or loud or rich or stupid. If I went to Iowa State, I would think the same about Des Moines. I lived in Tucson and I hold the same steretotypes against Scottsdale and Paradise Valley and Gilbert.

I hear two guys behind me introducing themselves. One is a soldier, National Guard, just got back from Iraq. Tells the other guy the military changed his life. The other is in the Job Corps and is training to be a plumber. Tells the other guy that that's why he's doing this; get a job and make up for some of the bad stuff he did when he was kid, make a living and turn himself around. Two regular guys, coming from this city that I have convinced myself to hate, doing what they can do to make a life for themselves, telling their story to a complete stranger with no hesitation or embarrassment.

For God's sake. It's not Pittsburgh's problem, right? Isn't it mine?

Cab 380 pulls up. I hastily pick up my bags, walk down the wooden stairs, wave the cab down. The driver, a young, husky, scraggly white guy, rolls down his window.

"You're going to the airport, right?"
"Yeah, the La Quinta."
"Alright, get in."
"Whoa, whoa, man, hold on, man!"

There are two guys behind me, different guys, but both black, like the soldier and the plumber.

It is worth noting that a person tends to learn some things when you travel a lot. One, the vast majority of people who travel by air are white, and the vast majority of the people who work in the airport are not. Two, most nice cars are driven by white people, and if a black person is driving a nice car, he will probably get pulled over by the cops at some point. (No, this doesn't just happen in episodes of Family Matters and in movies, I've actually witnessed this happen.) Three, many non-white people take buses to travel long distances. I am not going to analyze why this is the way it is; just know that this is indeed the way it is.

"Hold on for what, I'm taking this guy to the airport, you're not going to the airport."
"Hey, man, we fuckin' called this cab, man!"
"No, you fuckin' didn't, I got this guy, that's it!"
This would have been a good time to turn to the guys and explain to them that I actually did call this cab, they told me to wait for 380, and I did, and so I'm sorry, I can call another one for them if they want. Instead, I stand there.
"Hey why you gotta fuckin' use that language with us, dude?"
"THEY CALLED THAT CAB!!!!!!!"
A black woman near the bus entrance has begun to yell at the driver.
"If you swear at me, I'm gonna fuckin' swear at you, man, now I'm going to the airport!"
"Fuck you, man, this is bullshit, man."
"Fuck you, he's got this fuckin' cab, now get the fuck out of the way."
I get in the backseat and shut the door.
"FUCK YOU!" " THAT IS BULLSHIT!" "ASSHOLE!" "MOTHERFUCKER!"
The people at the bus entrance have taken notice and are officially beside themeselves. The bus driver gives them the finger, and my first ever role as a supporting actor in the production of an extremely ugly racial incident is complete.

Scene.

Two or three minutes later, we're on the one of the beltways, stuck in traffic.
"Hey, I'm sorry about that, those people are just ignorant."
The little ID card on the dash says his name is Adam something, and he has a number of tattoos on his arms. I tell him not to worry about it, and launch into a very unsettled-sounding explanation of how unfortunate it was that that happened, because blah blah blah and it looked bad and who knows what else. He waits for me to finish, then -
"Yeah, man, it's stupid. I swear, they're all idiots. I'm going to the airport, which is like fifteen miles east, and all of them want me to take them to the Hill District,"
Wait for it, wait for it,
"and there's no fucking way I'm ever gonna go there."
I think it's one of those things where you had to be there, in the backseat with me. Then you would have heard it, and you would have felt how icy it was, and you would have seen everything I saw when I heard him say it. I think that even if you didn't know that the Hill District was the poor, black part of the city, you would have figure it out instantly, and you would have seen dilapidated houses and broken streets and glass on the sidewalks and weeds and maybe broken down cars and decrepit buildings. I don't know if you would have seen buses, white sheets, rope, trees, fires, marches, fire hoses, guns, night sticks, loud music, sirens. I don't know if you would have seen any of those things, but I did, and right then and there I lost hope for both of us. As I type and backspace and add punctuation and read what I have written, over and over and over again, I lose hope for both of us.
Because, as I sat in the backseat of the car, stinging from the impact of what had just happened, I simply couldn't think of a way out. Was the driver wrong for being a racist? Yes, but his parents probably were, and the kids he went to school with, and the people he worked with, and apparently every time he picks up a white person black people yell at him. What do you do about that? Were the people at the station wrong for thinking the cab driver was a racist? Even though he was just doing his job, he did take me over them, and it looked bad, and plus he really was a racist. What do you do about that? How do you change the way that looks? What about me? Do I hold the cab and give a sermon? Or do as I did, shirk quietly in the backseat and hope that it all goes away, the same way a guy who was afraid of getting mugged or shot would?
I asked him about the Penguins game, and he didn't know. I already knew there was a game. It is so incredibly far to my hotel that it gets dark before we get there. I tipped him 20%. He thanked me and wished me a good night as I carried my bags to the lobby. I didn't turn around.

Scene.

Sitting by myself in a four person booth. There's an old joke that La Quinta is Spanish for "next to Denny's". Can't argue with that. A cute waitress approaches my table to take my order. I don't know about you, but a cute waitress giving you a big smile is not something you prepare yourself for when eating at Denny's. I manage to look her in the eye and give a half-smile back. I ask what the specials are, and she suggests the cinnamon raisin french toast. I order the cinnamon raisin french toast.

It is dark, and the street outside is wet with melted snow. Yellow from streetlights and headlights shines overhead. The menu says I am in Moon Township, PA. A light snow begins to fall, which means nothing other than it is prettier, because snow it's already covering everything except the asphalt and concrete.

A family of probably eleven or twelve walk in, shaking snow off their hats and jackets. It looks like there are moms and dads and brothers and sisters and cousins all, and everyone gets to be at least two. They take up two booths across the non-smoking area from me, smiling, laughing, telling jokes, thankful to be inside and given an opportunity to eat. Two of the girls are about my age, and they both have really beautiful skin, almost the exact opposite of mine. It is a unique shade and it makes me jealous. Next to them, a couple is eating dinner with their infant child in his high chair, and he is playing with his food and squirming all over the place. His parents are trying to calm him down but I really wish they wouldn't, because he's not making noise, so why not let this little boy be amused with his own life?

The waitress brings my food, and she says she brought extra syrup. I tell myself that she did this because she thinks I'm sweet, and for the sake of the story we will stick with that. Her name is Shelley. Her dark brown hair is in a ponytail and as she takes the order of the people in the booth next to me, I hear her laugh. It's a phenomenal laugh. It starts on a fairly high pitch and stays the same for three sounds and then goes up just a little bit at the end. Her laugh makes me sad that she has to work at Denny's on a Friday night in late December when it's snowing and everyone with that kind of laugh should be at home with her mom and dad or her boyfriend in front of the fireplace watching old movies.

It's warm inside the restaurant. Temperature aside, from my experience, the colder it is outside, the warmer you feel inside. The party of 12 has just gotten their food, the couple is wrapping it up with their kid, Shelley has just refilled my water. Christmas carols are playing, pleasantly, on the speakers overhead. It's warm, and Christmas carols are playing, and I am 2500 miles away from everything I know. I am alone, but I look around and everything is okay, for a few minutes at least, and I am happy about that.

What child is this, who, laid to rest,
On Mary's lap is sleeping?
Whom angels greet with anthems sweet,
While shepherds watch are keeping?

Just because of that laugh, I order a piece of pie. I'm full but goddamn it, I'm ordering a piece of pie.

This, this is Christ the King,
Whom shepherds guard and angels sing:
Haste, haste to bring him laud,
The babe, the son of Mary
